clinical_study.brief_title: Kappa Opioid Receptor Imaging in Depression (KOR Depression)
clinical_study.official_title: Kappa Opioid Receptor Imaging in Depression (KOR Depression)

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to use positron emission tomography (PET) imaging to measure the activity of the kappa opioid receptor (KOR) in the brains of depressed and non-depressed individuals.

detailed_description.textblock: The kappa opioid receptor (KOR) has been implicated in the etiology of fear, threat, and anhedonia in animal models of human depression psychopathology. Herein, we propose to study the KOR in vivo using positron emission tomography, and we will also measure the activity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA)-axis in all study participants. We propose to recruit up to N=50 medication-free individuals using a transdiagnostic approach, measure their KOR-selective radioligand [11C]LY2795050 volumes of distribution (VT), an equivalent of KOR availability using positron emission tomography (PET) and study the role of the KOR in mediating the quality and severity of the depressive phenotype.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The original PI, Alexander Neumeister, left NYULMC. No data was analyzed.

primary_outcome.measure: [11C]LY2795050 volume of distribution (VT) values in specific brain regions of asymptomatic vs mildly symptomatic vs moderately symptomatic vs severely symptomatic individuals
primary_outcome.description: To use the KOR radioligand [11C]LY2795050 and PET to examine the relation between KOR availability in the ventral striatum and amygdala, and the full dimensional spectrum of threat and loss symptomatology, and reward responsiveness.

study_pop.textblock: Subjects are between the ages of 18-55, are medically healthy and not currently taking any medications to treat any medical illness, have been diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) or will be as a result of this study, or are healthy control.
